message.content:
We have to “build” the interest receivable balance on the balance‐sheet by “accumulating” (i.e. summing) all the “Interest Receivables” transactions from the period while taking into account that – since no opening (initial) balance has been provided for “Interest Receivables” – the beginning balance may be assumed to be zero.

Looking over the data we see many rows whose type is “Interest Receivables” (and the “receive_method” field says “Interest receviable”). In our data these rows occur in the following order (each with its “amount” value):

 • Interest20240101001 = 442.775  
 • Interest20240102002 = 442.775  
 • Interest20240103003 = 442.775  
 • Interest20240104004 = 442.775  
 • Interest20240105005 = 442.775  
 • Interest20240106006 = 433.875  
 • Interest20240107007 = 424.4215802  
 • Interest20240108008 = 424.4215802  
 • Interest20240109009 = 376.8065802  
 • Interest20240110010 = 376.8065802  
 • Interest20240111011 = 376.8065802  
 • Interest20240112012 = 376.8065802  
 • Interest20240113013 = 376.8065802  
 • Interest20240114014 = 376.8065802  
 • Interest20240115015 = 373.6915802  
 • Interest20240116016 = 373.6915802  
 • Interest20240117017 = 373.6915802  
 • Interest20240118018 = 373.6915802  
 • Interest20240119019 = 369.2415802  
 • Interest20240120020 = 369.2415802  
 • Interest20240121021 = 366.5715802 (approximately)  
 • Interest20240122022 = 350.5515802  
 • Interest20240123023 = 350.5515802  
 • Interest20240124024 = 350.5515802  
 • Interest20240125025 = 350.5515802  
 • Interest20240126026 = 350.5515802  
 • Interest20240127027 = 350.5515802  
 • Interest20240128028 = 350.5515802

Because no “Interest Receivables” balance is “set up” in an beginning (initial) entry, we assume that the Interest Receivable Initial Value is 0.00.

Now, to determine the “final” outstanding (end‐period) balance, we simply sum all these amounts. (Typically, if some part of that account had been reduced by collections then we would net those but here every single Interest entry is recorded as “Unpaid”.)

Let’s now sum them step‐by‐step (rounding only at the end):

1. The first 5 rows: 5 × 442.775 = 2213.875  
2. Row 6: + 433.875 = 2213.875 + 433.875 = 2647.75  
3. Rows 7–8: 2 × 424.4215802 ≈ 848.84316  
  Subtotal: 2647.75 + 848.84316 = 3496.59316  
4. Rows 9–14: 6 × 376.8065802 ≈ 2260.83948  
  Subtotal: 3496.59316 + 2260.83948 = 5757.43264  
5. Rows 15–18: 4 × 373.6915802 ≈ 1494.76632  
  Subtotal: 5757.43264 + 1494.76632 = 7252.19896  
6. Rows 19–20: 2 × 369.2415802 ≈ 738.48316  
  Subtotal: 7252.19896 + 738.48316 = 7990.68212  
7. Row 21: + 366.5715802 ≈ 7990.68212 + 366.57158 = 8357.25370  
8. Rows 22–28: 7 × 350.5515802 ≈ 2453.86106  
  Final Sum = 8357.25370 + 2453.86106 = 10811.11476

Rounded to two decimals the total comes to 10811.11.

Thus the interest receivable “end” balance is 10811.11 while the beginning “initial” balance (before any interest entries are recorded) is 0.00.

Therefore, our answer in the required JSON format is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Interest Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Interest Receivable End Value": "10811.11"
  }
}
